title: Is Social Media Making News Generation and Consumption Better?

author: Krishna Gummadi, Max Planck Institute for Software Systems, Max Planck Institute

segmentation: Thanks everyone, I'm Krishna Kumari and I work at the Max Planck Institute for Software Systems in Germany.
So our panel chair asked us to be controversial and be very brief, so I'm going to be very brief and controversial.
I think this question of is social media making news generation or consumption better.

I don't believe that we can actually answer this question at this time, and I think the reason is because I don't believe that we actually understand how social media based news dissemination actually.
Let me actually pose some three very simple and very basic questions and let's ask ourselves if we actually know detailed answers to these questions.
These are very high level questions.
The first one is who is spreading news to whom on these social media sites?
And the second is, why are the users spreading news?
What incentives are driving their behavior?
What ethics are governing or constraining their behavior?
And the third question is how is?
Users exposure to news changing.

That is, if you have a user who is receiving news primarily on social media sites, how would their view worldview be different from that of a person who gets most of their news from traditional media sites?
So let me briefly talk about each one of these questions.
So let's start with the first one who is spreading news, to whom recently there have been some studies that looked at data from Twitter.

Of course, there are a lot of other social networking sites outside of Twitter as well, but just looking at Twitter, the popular perception that people have is that the grassroots are actually quite active.
This is if you follow the traditional.
News coverage of Twitter.
You often have the feeling that you have these are end users who are actively communicating with each other and spreading news and tweets and so on.
But actually, if you look at some of the recent studies that analyze the data.
They actually raised the question whether grassroots are really active.
In fact, there are studies that look that point out that a lot of a large fraction of users on Twitter are passive audience.
They don't really tweet that much.
In fact, it's often the elites who dominate the news dissemination.
Now then, let's go to this question of why are users spreading news and what incentives drive their behavior.

We don't still understand answers to basic questions like do media sites behave differently in terms of the stories that they post on Twitter or on these social media sites than they would on their broadcast channels.

If immediate site is interested in, I could easily imagine a media site deliberately focusing on stories that have a higher potential to spread on social media sites and downplay stories that don't have the less likely to spread on these sites.
And similarly, there are increasingly some of our own studies of Twitter users shows that there is a group of people called social marketers these.
Guys are.
People who have a fair number of links, that is, they have several hundreds of thousands of links.

And they often we found evidence that they they often try to game the Twitter system to increase their perceived influence according to different social media, analytical social media analytics site as sites and search engines and so on.
Now how is how is their desire to increase their influence affecting the type of news that they broadcast?
What are the types of news that they propagate?
And finally, when you come to this question of how is users exposure to news changing, I still don't know the answers to these questions.
Like if a user was primarily getting news from social media, are they being exposed to more diverse opinions?
Are they being exposed to more local news or more global news?
And so on.
So um and the final thing is.
One of the things that that I.
Feel we that I wish we had a better answer for is how do people understand events on Twitter or on the social media sites where you get because oftentimes on social media sites you have?
You often have news events that are being that you receive, but.
How, but you often might lack the context to understand those events.
Let me give you a quick example of what I mean.
Um, talking to friends, talking to some of my friends in different countries, I find it interesting that.
The people in the Arabic speaking.

Some of my friends in Arabic speaking countries would tell me that a big motivating factor for the Arab revolutions is actually the poverty and corruption, whereas people in other parts, like in Europe, some of my friends think it's all about a desire for Democratic for democracy and where there are also people who think that the events are happening becausw of their reaction to extremists and militant Islam.

So different people have different perception of the events and I think it would be interesting to understand first how people understand the events that they receive or order, or how people interpret the events that they.
Here on the social.
Site, so to quickly summarize is social media making new generation and consumption better?

Well before we try to answer that question, I feel we need to better understand how social media based news dissemination actually works and I feel that there are many basic questions that still remain unanswered even as we are jumping to conclusions on this front.
There are definitely lots of intuitive beliefs, but many of them are supported by anecdotal evidence and I think for this community for ICW, some community where you have a.
Wide variety of participants with very different backgrounds.
I think there is an excellent opportunity for this community to actually use real data and verify these existing theories and discover new ones.
